York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; World War, 1914-1918 -- Tennessee -- History;Fentress County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sergeant Alvin C. York (1889-1964) and his bride, Gracie Williams, on their wedding day, June 7, 1919. He is dressed in his uniform while she is wearing a wedding gown and carries a bouquet of flowers. They are standing before a tree. Text underneath the image states, "Before Sergeant York went to war he had given an option to his mountain sweetheart - she could have him for the takin' when he got back."

Alvin York was one of the most decorated American soldiers in World War I. He was awarded a Medal of Honor and a French Croix de Guerre for taking a German machine gun nest and assisting in the capture of 132 German soldiers. He married Gracie Loretta Williams on June 7, 1919. The wedding ceremony was performed by Tennessee Governor A. H. Roberts.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Preview of film "Sergeant York" at Knickerbocker Theatre, Nashville, Tennessee, July 1941. Front row, left to right: Joe Oehmig, Governor Prentice Cooper, Mrs. Gracie York, Sergeant Alvin York, Mayor Thomas L. Cummings.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wiles-Hood
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Having refused a number of previous offers to depict his life story on film, Sergeant Alvin C. York authorized in 1940 the movie that would be entitled "Sergeant York." Released in 1941, the film was directed by Howard Hawks and starred Gary Cooper in the title role. It received 11 Oscar nominations and won two including Best Actor Gary Cooper for his portrayal of York.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houses; Historic buildings
York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Fentress County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Alvin C. York home, a large square building with four columns fronting a two-story porch, and a large sunroom on the right.

The Alvin C. York home was built in 1922 by Orestes Crowley. In 1925, York opened a general store across from the house and purchased a two-story grist mill on the Wolf River near his land. The property was sold to the State of Tennessee in several purchases from 1967 to 1984. The propery was eventually added to the National Register of Historic Places (1973) and listed as a National Historic Landmark (1976).

The return features the primary votes for Horton and Gwinn for Governor; Dodson, Hull, and Todd for U.S. Senator (long term); Brock and Neal for U.S. Senator (short term); Albright, Mitchell, and Owen for Congress; Anderson and Officer for State Senator; and Stockton and Taylor for Floterial Representative.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping declaring "Saturday Tag Day for York." The article announces that all Nashvillians will have an opportunity to help the hero by giving money to a fund which would pay the mortgage on the York farm. The article includes a list of amounts already donated. The Rotary Club has given $390.50, and the Cleveland Club has made an offer to help York find opportunities to preach.

Alvin York was one of the most decorated American soldiers in World War I. He was awarded a Medal of Honor and a French Croix de Guerre for taking a German machine gun nest and assisting in the capture of 132 German soldiers. The York property, later to become a state park, was paid for by the Nashville Rotary Club but was built in York's hometown of Pall Mall in Fentress County.

Alvin York was one of the most decorated American soldiers in World War I. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Marriage
York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; York, Gracie Loretta Williams, 1900-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Article from unidentified newspaper is entitled "Wedding Bells for Sergt. York" and written by R. G. Fields. It describes the bride, "seventeen," her father, "A. F. Williams, former circuit court clerk of Fentress County," and some of the wedding gifts: wedding ring given by the Steif Jewelery Company, a brooch from the state suffrage association, a wrist watch from the Nashville Rotary Club, and a solid silver bowl engraved with the bride's initials, "G. W. Y.," from Maj. E. B. Stahlman.

Among the guests were Gov. A. H. Roberts, who came in a special car over the Tennessee Central Railroad, to perform the wedding ceremony; J. M. Littleton, Chattanooga; E. B. Stahlman, Nashville; and C. E. James, Chattanooga.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Marriage
York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; York, Gracie Loretta Williams, 1900-1984
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper article entitled "York Married to Miss Williams" by Robert G. Fields (staff correspondent). "Miss Williams, who is the youngest of thirteen children was attended by three maids of honor, Misses Ida Wright, Maud Brier, and Adella Darwin, while the groom's best man was a comrade in arms, Sergt. Henry Clay Brier, U. S. A."

The marriage ceremony was performed beneath a large beech tree by Tennessee Governor Albert H. Roberts in Pall Mall on June 7, 1919, before two thousand people. Gov. Roberts and Maj. E. B. Stahlman, owner and publisher of the Nashville Banner, delivered the principal addresses. The Fentress County sheriff, under strict orders from Gov. Roberts, prohibited any filming of the ceremony.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Certificates; Fund raising
York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Rotary Club of Nashville -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Certificate to Nashville Banner from Nashville Rotary Club for the first subscription made to the York Farm Fund. The Banner had the honor of "starting the ball rolling" with the donation of $50. Subsequently nearly every Banner employee made an individual donation of $1 or more. The Nashville Rotary Club hoped to raise $15,000 for the hero.

The Rotary Club of Nashville joined with other Tennessee clubs in collecting funds so they could present York with a home and a farm. Unfortunately, they raised only enough to give him an unfinished home and a healthy mortgage. As late as 1922, the deed remained in the hands of the Nashville Rotary Club.

Alvin York was one of the most decorated American soldiers in World War I. He was awarded a Medal of Honor and a French Croix de Guerre for capturing a German machine gun nest and assisting in the capture of 132 German soldiers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Austrian-born Felix de Weldon, who became the foremost American sculptor of the 20th century, specialized in representations of military heroes, statesmen, and religious leaders. His masterpiece was The Flag Raising on Iwo Jima. The York monument (1968) reads "Armed with his rifle and pistol, his courage and skill, one Tennessean silenced a German battalion of 35 machine guns, killing 25 enemy soldiers, and capturing 132 in the Argonne Forest of France, October 8, 1918."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fentress County is located in northeast Middle Tennessee on the picturesque Cumberland Plateau. The Tennessee General Assembly created Fentress County from parts of Overton and Morgan counties on November 28, 1823. The county was named in honor of James Fentress, Speaker of the Tennessee House of Representatives, who had assisted in passing the enabling legislation for the new county.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Early laundry required plenty of soft water -- lye or soda could be put in hard water to soften it, but lye is quite caustic. Two wash-forms are needed: one for the two tubs for suds, and the other for blueing and starching-tubs. Also necessary are a large wooden dipper, (metal can rust), two or three pails, a grooved washboard, and a clothesline.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Campaigns & battles; War; Infantry; Conscientious objectors

York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Pattullo, George, 1879-1967; Soldiers; United States -- Biography; World War, 1914-1918 -- Personal narratives, American; Saturday Evening Post; United States -- Army -- Infantry Regiment, 328th
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Alvin C. York's heroism went unnoticed in the United States, even in Tennessee, until the publication of the April 26, 1919, issue of the Saturday Evening Post. In an article titled "The Second Elder Gives Battle" (pp. 1-4 ff.), journalist George Patullo first told the story that would soon become legend. The Post's readership totaled over 2 million people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: George Pattullo
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Journalist Patullo learned of York's story while touring battlefields in 1919. Sergeant Alvin C. York, a poorly-educated Tennessee mountaineer, was a national hero, decorated for acts of bravery as a soldier in Company G, 328th Infantry during World War I. York was awarded his nation's highest decoration, the Medal of Honor, for his actions on October 8, 1918, during the Meuse-Argonne Offensive against the German forces.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Mark Twain Hotel in Jamestown, Tennessee. The hotel is a two-story building with a veranda/balcony on the first and second floors. oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fentress County was Alvin York's home county. This photo was taken during meetings between York and Hollywood producers related to a proposed film, "Sergeant York," based on his World War I exploits. Photographer was Albert Franklin Ganier Sr., who captured photos of the meeting between York and Warner Brothers filmmakers as they researched the film. Mark Twain never lived in Jamestown but referred to it in his writings, frequently calling it "Obedstown" after the nearby Obeds River.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Automobiles
York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; World War, 1914-1918 -- Tennessee -- History;Motion pictures; Agricultural high schools; Technical institutes; Jamestown (Tenn.); Alvin C. York Agricultural Institute
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The York Agricultural Institute, showing the front of the school building and several vehicles parked in the drive. York established the institute in Jamestown, the Fentress County seat, in an effort to provide rural children with an education. The institute was purchased by the state during the Great Depression and continues to be operated by the State of Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pall Mall in Fentress County was Alvin York's home town. York founded the institute as a private institution in 1926. In 1937 it was transferred to the State Board of Education. Photograph by Albert Franklin Ganier Sr., who captured images of the meeting between York and Warner Brothers as they researched the film, "Sergeant York."

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mules; Harnesses; Bridles; Farmers; Farms
Ganier, Albert Franklin, 1883-1973; York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Sergeant York (Motion picture); Fentress County (Tenn.); Mules -- Tennessee -- Fentress County
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An unidentified farmer is standing on a device that appears to be a skid elevated by 3 or more long wooden dowels. A mule is harnessed to it by two chains and a rope is attached to the left side of the mule's mouth area known as a side pull. The field is partially plowed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A side pull is a bitless bridle. Reins are attached to rings on either side of the animal's muzzle. When both reins are pulled, pressure is placed on the animal's nose, cuing a halt. Pulling on one rein cues the horse to turn its head in that direction; pulling on the left rein cues the horse to turn left, etc. Mules were a key element in Tennessee's farm economy. Between 1870 and 1880, mules replaced oxen as the main work stock in Tennessee.

Ganier, Albert Franklin, 1883-1973; York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Sergeant York (Motion picture); Fentress County (Tenn.); Tennessee -- Social life and customs; Appalachians (People) -- Tennessee; Rural families -- Appalachian region
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A man with a long stick (4 or more feet) in his hands sits on the stoop of a rough wooden cabin. He wears frayed and patched overalls with a shirt, suit jacket, and hat. His left shoe appears to be untied.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fentress County is located in northeast Middle Tennessee on the picturesque Cumberland Plateau. The county initially formed the state's border with Kentucky, but when Pickett County was established in 1881, the upper part of Fentress was included in the new county. Both the county and its seat, Jamestown, were named for surveyor James Fentress. The Wolf River rises at the base of the Cumberland Plateau in Fentress County.

Ganier, Albert Franklin, 1883-1973; York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Sergeant York (Motion picture); Fentress County (Tenn.); Tennessee -- Social life and customs; Appalachians (People) -- Tennessee; Rural families -- Appalachian region
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A man with a long stick (4 or more feet) in his hands sits on the stoop of a rough wooden cabin. He wears frayed and patched overalls with a shirt, suit jacket, and hat. A small blond boy between 6 and 8 is standing on the ground near the left corner of the porch. The boy's clothes are much like the man's. The house is in very poor repair. Another building on the man's right appears to be in somewhat better condition.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Appalachian region of the U.S., while abundant in natural resources and rich in potential, lags behind the rest of the nation in its economic growth. Its people have not shared proportionately in the country's prosperity. The region's uneven past development, with its traditional reliance on a few basic industries and a marginal agriculture, has failed to provide the economic base that might produce vigorous, self-sustaining growth.

Ganier, Albert Franklin, 1883-1973; York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Sergeant York (Motion picture); Tennessee -- Social life and customs; Appalachians (People) -- Tennessee; Rural families - Appalachian region
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A small hillside farmhouse reached by a deeply rutted road, with fist-sized stones placed in the deepest ruts. No powerlines or chimneys are in evidence, only a pipe sticking out of the roof. One small window and door can be seen. A little girl stands near the door. The farmhouse area is fenced, and the gate appears to have been recently repaired.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Even by Depression standards, the Tennessee Valley region was in sad shape in 1933. Much of the land had been farmed too hard for too long, eroding and depleting the soil. Crop yields had fallen, along with farm incomes. The best timber had been cut. The electricity generated by TVA dams was about to generate a dramatic change in regional life.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oxen had served as a valuable beast of burden for Appalachian farmers since the 1700s. As settlers crossed the Appalachian Mountains into Tennessee and Kentucky, the oxen helped to pull wagons, log forests, draw plows, break up land, remove rocks and boulders, raise barns, pull all types of implements, and power water pumps and sorghum presses.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Big South Fork's most prominent feature is the river gorge cutting through the softer Mississippian-age rock beneath the hard Pennsylvanian capstone of the Cumberland Plateau. Water is the most influential agent of geologic change in the Big South Fork region. Over time, water action has left many unique and amazing geologic features in the area.

She has a crutch under each arm. Both appear to be dressed in their best. Behind each of them is a wooden ladderback chair. A sunbonnet hangs on one chair, and a man's hat is on the other.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Between the stock market crash of 1929 and the end of World War II, Tennessee transformed from a rural landscape with limited access to electricity to a state capable of hosting the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) and part of the Manhattan Project within its borders. Congress passed the Tennessee Valley Authority Act, one of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal programs, in 1933, providing not only electricity but also much-needed jobs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Resolutions, Legislative
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: House Joint Resolution 69 from 1919, the 61st General Assembly, recommending that Corporal Alvin C. York be promoted to the rank of colonel.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Resolution sponsored by Representatives Frogge & David
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Alvin York was one of the most decorated American soldiers in World War I. He was awarded a Medal of Honor and a French Croix de Guerre for taking a German machine gun nest and assisting in the capture of 132 German soldiers. Resolution adopted April 11 and concurred in the Senate on April 12. Resolution resulted in York's holding the rank of colonel in the Tennessee State Guard during World War II.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four-page printed program for the ceremonies surrounding the unveiling of the statue of Alvin York on the Capitol grounds. Festivities scheduled include the 81st Airborne Division band, the York Institute band, the 82nd Airborne Division Color Guard, an address by Buford Ellington, and a benediction.

The statue of Alvin York was created by Felix De Weldon, sculptor of the famous Iwo Jima monument in Washington D.C. The statue was installed in 1968 to honor York on the Capitol grounds in Nashville, Tennessee.

York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; World War, 1914-1918 -- Tennessee -- History;United States -- Army -- Airborne Division, 82nd; Commemorative postage stamps
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An envelope featuring the first release of the Alvin York commemorative postage stamp. The stamp features a photograph of York in his service hat and the insignia of the 82nd Infantry Division. The envelope is stamped "First Day of Issue" and "Washington DC, May 3 2000, 20066." The left corner of the envelope features the seal of the Sergeant York Patriotic Foundation, including an image of York with his signature and the address of the foundation in Pall Mall, Tennessee.

Alvin York was one of the most decorated American soldiers in World War I. He was awarded a Medal of Honor and a French Croix de Guerre for taking a German machine gun nest and assisting in the capture of 132 German soldiers. The stamp featuring York was released in 2000 in a U.S. Postal Service Salute to War Heroes. Others honored include Audie Murphy, Omar Bradley, and John L. Hines.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This typed, 5" x 8", two-sided card maintained in the Tennessee Adjutant General's files displays basic biographical and military information concerning Alvin C. York and the awarding of his Medal of Honor. Categories of information are set, and there is a separate section for the specific citation related to the Medal of Honor.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Storer, Walter Henry, 1898-1974
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Dr. Walter H. Storer Photograph Collection, ca. 1930-1955
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Medal of Honor, the highest military decoration given by the U.S. government, was awarded to Alvin C. York for his heroism in World War I. He also received the Legion of Honor, the Croix de Guerre, the Croce di Guerra, and the World War I Victory Medal. The Tennessee Adjutant General's Office kept additional card indexing systems for recipients of the Bronze Star, the Distinguished Service Cross, and foreign decorations.

York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; York, Gracie Loretta Williams, 1900-1984; Burial; Cemeteries--Tennessee; Sepulchral monuments; Tombs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Gravesite of Alvin C. York and his wife Gracie L. York. The site is decorated with a stone cross and stone angel and two tombstones. There is a flagpole immediately behind the site. 35mm slide labeled "York Memorial 4."

York died on September 2, 1964, and was buried in Wolf River Cemetery in Pall Mall, TN. His funeral was attended by Gov. Frank Clement and Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, the latter attending as personal representative of President Lyndon B. Johnson. During World War II, Ridgway commanded the 82nd Division, the division in which York served during World War I.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Warner Brothers producer Jesse Lasky had sought to secure movie rights to the York story since 1919. York finally relented around 1940 when Lasky argued that Americans needed inspiration in light of the war in Europe. The film became the highest-grossing movie of 1941 and was nominated for eleven Oscars.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964 -- Statues; De Weldon, Felix, 1907-2003; Tennessee -- Capital and capitol; Ellington, Buford, 1907-1972; Chamber of Commerce (Nashville, Tenn.); Statues; Luncheons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This 5" x 7" card is an invitation from Tennessee Gov. Buford Ellington to the unveiling of the York statue on the Capitol grounds, December 13, 1968. The recipient is also invited to a Nashville Chamber of Commerce luncheon at the Andrew Jackson Hotel honoring the occasion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chamber of Commerce (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The ten-foot statue honoring Alvin C. York on the Tennessee Capitol grounds was created by Austrian-American sculptor Felix de Weldon. De Weldon's work encompasses over one thousand two hundred public memorials, displayed on seven continents. He is best known for his masterpiece "The Flag Raising on Iwo Jima," the Marine Corps War Memorial.
